entry.title: Embedded Finance in SAP: SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity with J.P. Morgan Payments
entry.content:
Enterprises are rethinking how to connect banking capabilities with ERP processes to maximize business value. Key questions include:

  • How to make payments, reconciliation, and cash visibility seamless and fully integrated between banks and the ERP system?
  • How to adopt innovations like real-time payments or real-time cash balances without launching a new IT project every time a banking service gets added?
  • How to unlock the combined value of invoice and payment data in the ERP alongside the cash and financial data held by banks?

SAP and J.P. Morgan asked themselves the same questions. And as a result decided to collaborate and partner even closer to bring more value to shared clients by better integrating the capabilities of both by accelerating adoption of SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC) to deliver J.P. Morgan bank services embedded in ERP processes.

With SAP MBC, corporates get direct, standardized access to J.P. Morgan banking services directly integrated into their payment and cash processes. As a result corporates can scale new services faster, without custom builds and with minimal ongoing maintenance and benefit from the seamless and many times real time data flow to get the decision advantage crucial in todays fast and ever changing business world.

What you can expect

  • Seamless connectivity: Integrate J.P. Morgan services via SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity to connect your SAP ERP to J.P. Morgan Payments using standardized, bank-approved channels.
  • Automate payments and reporting: The J.P. Morgan Payments Adapter 2.0 supports file-based payments (ACH, checks, virtual cards, wires—including FX) and real-time payments across the U.S., EU, UK, Australia, Singapore, Malaysia, and Hong Kong.
  • Real-time insights: Access instant reporting and reconciliation, view account balances and transaction details, and track payments through advanced APIs.
  • Easy implementation: Prebuilt adapters and help you go live quickly and securely
  • AI-powered treasury: Leverage SAP’s cloud data foundation and AI-driven capabilities to interact with J.P. Morgan and elevate treasury operations.

Who can benefit

  • New and existing J.P. Morgan clients using SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud, Private Cloud, or On-Premise) or SAP ECC (6.0+)
  • Organizations operating on J.P. Morgan Access, with support for multi-bank reporting across non–J.P. Morgan DDAs
  • Teams seeking flexible connection options through SAP MBC to tailor integrations to specific business needs

This collaboration meets clients where they are simplifying connectivity while strengthening control and visibility at the same time, and accelerating access to new banking innovations, all embedded in SAP ERP processes.

Want to know more?

  • SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity 
    • https://www.sap.com/germany/products/financial-management/multi-bank-connectivity.html 
    • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MULTI_BANK_CONNECTIVITY
  • J.P. Morgan SAP Integration:
    • https://partners.jpmorgan.com/sap_s4hana.html
  • SAP and J.P. Morgan Partnership:
    • https://digital.jpmorgan.com/jpmorgan-with-sap/index.html

Still want to know more?

Meet us at the AFP Conference in Boston on October 26–29 or attend SAP and J.P. Morgan session at the AFP and J.P. Morgan Booth on Tuesday Oct 28th  2-2.30pm local Boston time

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‑centric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points – like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations – go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances – short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted – and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you’re moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it’s crucial to have full transparency into what’s actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it’s difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product’s environmental footprint – enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action – whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms – survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center – delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it’s routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we’re speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We’ve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their “now4tomorrow” program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You’ll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: Drive Project Success Through Co-Innovation: SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council Q4 Update!
entry.content:
Q4/2025 ESAC Workstreams Are Live!

We’re excited to bring you the latest SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC) updates for Q4/2025! View the full list of active workstreams  here.

ESAC is our co-innovation program designed to shape the future of SAP Enterprise Support (Foundational Support), in direct collaboration with customers like you. This program gives you early access to innovative SAP Enterprise Support services and lets you influence SAP’s future support offerings. Participation is included at no extra cost and helps you gain the latest insights for your ongoing projects.

What’s New This Quarter? We’re kicking off 3 new workstreams this quarter to help you accelerate value:

  • Continuous quality check*: Technical Preparation for SAP Signavio Process Insights and Intelligence
  • E-Learning : Increase your sales teams’ efficiency with SAP Sales Cloud
  • Release Navigator: Upgrade Resources for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (see blog here)

Open Workstreams? Don’t miss your chance to join these still open workstreams:

  • Continuous quality check: Transformation assessment for SAP IBP Tactical Supply Planning
  • Continuous quality check: Deployment readiness check for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

Now Generally Available? The following services, initiated in previous quarters, are now available to all customers:

  • Continuous quality check: Deployment readiness for SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2
  • Continuous quality check: Deployment readiness check for SAP BTP
  • Continuous quality check: Deployment readiness check for SAP Datasphere (Q4)
  • Continuous quality check: GoingLive support for SAP Cloud Integration (Q4)
  • EGI*: SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine and Generative AI (Q4)

Get Involved? Be part of the innovation!

  • Visit ESAC on SAP Support Portal 
  • contact us:  esac@sap.com

Let’s shape the future of Enterprise Support together!

Your SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council Team

* CQC (Continuous quality check) = work with our experts to analyze your system based on real life system or solution data. You will receive a service report with an executive summary, findings and a detailed action plan to improve or mitigate risks.

EGI (Expert Guided Implementation) = EGI is a remote, multi-day workshop series where SAP experts guide your project team through the setup, configuration, or optimization of a specific SAP solution or process.

entry.title: Upgrade Tools & Resources - New Enterprise Support Advisory Council Pilot for Customers
entry.content:
Greetings SAP Community! 

Big news! At the beginning in Q4 2025, SAP Enterprise Support will provide a new pilot through the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC) focusing on the upgrades for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition customers.

 

Quick Links

 

Scope

We recognize that system upgrades can present challenges, such as downtime and adapting to new features. Tackling these issues head-on is essential to enhancing your upgrade experience.

Our primary goal is to empower you with the right tools and resources to manage your release readiness during upgrades. A streamlined upgrade process will allow you to unlock new functionalities and minimize potential disruptions. 

We will also introduce you to the release navigator, design to help you leverage SAP enablement resources, ensuring successful and beneficial upgrades for your business. This tool offers more than just guidance—it provides tangible resources tailored to your system landscape, including:

  • An overview of the release process, upgrade frameworks, and innovation roadmaps to guide your decision-making for SAP release planning and technical readiness.

 

Prerequisites

To fully benefit from the release navigator, there are a few prerequisites you'll need:

  • Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition system should be operational.
  • You should have completed at least one upgrade project or cycle.
  • Make sure you have a dedicated contact person available for communication and coordination.

 

Outcome

You’ll have access to a dedicated SAP Release Advisor, remote sessions, and self-service enablement tools ensuring you have the support you need every step of the way. After completion of this workstream, you will be well informed about the tools and resources available to support your upgrade process. We will also spend time identifying common pain points with upgrades and how SAP can better support these challenges.

 

Participation

  • This pilot is brought to you via the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC).
  • To find out more about the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council in general visit the website. 
  • Details of this workstream will soon be included on that page.
  • To register you interest please contact us via email: esac@sap.com:
    • Let us know your location / timezone, and state your interest in this pilot workstream.

entry.title: Migration Pathways Comprehensive Guide : From SD to RAR and SD RR to RAR in S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

With the introduction of SAP Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR), SAP has provided a modern and flexible solution for handling revenue recognition processes aligned with the accounting standards of IFRS 15 / ASC 606. As a result, legacy revenue recognition functionalities like SD Revenue Recognition (Sales and Distribution) are phased out in favor of RAR in SAP S/4HANA.

To facilitate this transition, SAP has provided guidance via release notes, FAQ notes, and SAP Help Portal documentation. These resources describe the supported system configurations, prerequisites, limitations, and data considerations for a smooth migration to RAR.

This blog post does not attempt to replicate that technical depth. Instead, it provides a visual summary of key migration scenarios that customers typically face when transitioning from Sales and Distribution (SD) or SD Revenue Recognition (SD RR) to Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR). It is intended to serve as a decision-support tool during the early planning and design phases of an RAR implementation project.

This blog post provides guidance on the various migration scenarios available in Revenue Accounting and Reporting. Whether you are planning to migrate to the Classic Contract Management version, adopt the Optimized Contract Management version, or transition existing classic contracts to the optimized version, this document will help you understand the options, prerequisites, and SAP Notes required for each path.

By providing a simplified, visual-first approach to complex scenarios, this document aims to help organizations make more informed, confident, and timely decisions as they move toward adopting RAR as their central revenue recognition engine in SAP S/4HANA Landscape.

Overview of Migration Pathways to RAR

In ECC, legacy SD or SD-RR data are migrated and processed via FARRIC_OL to create RAR Classic Contracts, which can then be upgraded to S/4HANA and can be migrated as RAR Optimized Contracts (OCM) in future, with the option to copy historical data from CCM contracts.

In S/4HANA, SD data is migrated and processed using FARRIC_OL to create RAR Optimized Contracts (OCM) or RAR Classic Contracts (CCM) which can be migrated as RAR Optimized Contracts (OCM) in future with copy of historical data from CCM.

 

Primary Details and Conditions for Consideration

  • In S/4HANA, SD Revenue Recognition (SD RR) is considered obsolete. Customers who have been utilizing SD RR in ECC and are transitioning to S/4HANA must migrate their data from SD RR to Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR).

 

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA 1909, you can use an optimized version of Revenue Accounting Contract Management. Further, with SAP S/4HANA 2020, SAP has added an optimized version of Inbound Processing. The optimized Contract Management focuses on performance optimizations, and additional features, such as day-based contract modifications. The optimized Inbound Processing allows for the real-time processing of operational documents.

The original version of Contract Management - also referred to as Revenue Accounting 1.3 for SAP S/4HANA - is referred to as Contract Management (Classic). The former version of Inbound Processing is referred to as Inbound Processing (Classic). The synonymous terms Classic Contract Management with the abbreviation CCM and Classic Inbound Processing with the abbreviation CIP are also used.

  • For contracts in the context of the (optimized) Contract Management version, you can also find the abbreviation OCM contract (Optimized Contract Management contract).
  • For contracts in the context of the Classic Contract Management version (Contract Management (Classic)), you can also find the abbreviation CCM contract (Classic Contract Management contract).

 

For improved readability, we will refer to OCM (Optimized Contract Management) and CCM (Classic Contract Management) in this document. Please keep in mind the corresponding versions of inbound processing associated with each.

The Optimized RAR version is exclusively available in S/4HANA and cannot be accessed in ECC. In ECC, only the Classic RAR version is provided. For more details see: Revenue Accounting Versus Revenue Accounting Classic | SAP Help Portal

Please note that RAR supports the following migration paths:

  • Migration to Classic RAR is only feasible if Classic Inbound Processing (CIP) is utilized.
  • Migration to Optimized RAR is only possible if Optimized Inbound Processing (OIP) is employed.

 

Other combinations are not permitted, even though they would technically function if a greenfield approach was taken (for instance, OCM generally works with both OIP and CIP, but there is no migration function available for migrating to CIP and OCM).

  • A prerequisite for migration to RAR is that the configuration of the RAR/SD integration scenario must be completed. For details see SAP Help: Integration with Sales and Distribution | SAP Help Portal

  • List of abbreviations used in this document for SAP components relevant for the migration scenarios:
    • ECC: Enterprise Central Component
    • S/4HANA: SAP Business Suite 4 SAP HANA
    • SD: Sales and Distribution
    • SD RR: Sales and Distribution Revenue Recognition (Component: SD-BIL-RR), ERP SD Revenue Recognition | SAP Help Portal
    • RAR: Revenue Accounting and Reporting
      • RAR Classic        
        • CCM: Classic Contract Management
        • CIP: Classic Inbound Processing
      • RAR Optimized
        • OCM: Optimized Contract Management
        • OIP: Optimized Inbound Processing


Migration Options

Scenario1: SD RR to RAR Migration

This chapter deals with the scenario if SD RR is used in ECC for revenue recognition and the customer wants to migrate to RAR.

Migration to RAR Classic is possible if SD RR legacy data is available. Upon migration to RAR Classic, the realized revenue will be obtained from SD Revenue Recognition if a sales document item is relevant for SD Revenue Recognition.

Migration to Optimized RAR is not possible since this RAR version is not available in ECC.

Important: The migration of SD Revenue Recognition legacy data is not supported for S/4HANA source systems. Therefore, the customers that use SD Revenue Recognition need to migrate to Revenue Accounting and Reporting before they convert ECC to S/4HANA.

SAP Note with the necessary migration guidance: 2733866 - Migration Guide for SD Revenue Recognition to Revenue Accounting and Reporting - SAP for Me

The below table outlines the possible Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR) migration scenarios from SD RR to RAR under the assumption that SD RR is in use.

Even if some of the scenarios mentioned above are not supported in SAP Standard migration process using the FARRIC_OL program, there can be additional technical alternatives which can be implemented in customer projects, e.g. by utilizing the Third-Party Migration API for Optimized RAR (FARR_INBOUND_EXT_MIGRATION_API, SAP Help: Operational Load for Third-Party Sender Components | SAP Help Portal). This option facilitates data migration from a variety of sources, offering flexibility for migration scenarios not supported by SD/RAR migration tools.

 

Visual Guidance Considering ECC to S/4HANA Conversion

Depending on your objectives, we recommend considering the following migration options:

Migration to RAR Optimized:

Scenario 3: Migration from SD to RAR Optimized if RAR Classic is already in use

If you are already using SD and RAR Classic and you aim to use Optimized RAR, there is an additional option which allows to migrate data from SD and copy some essential data (e.g. start/end dates, standalone selling price, recognized revenue amounts, cumulative distributed invoice amounts etc.) from existing classic RAR contracts into the newly created optimized RAR contracts.

entry.title: Minimizing SAP License Costs by optimizing SAP Authorizations with MOON Services
entry.content:
“MOON – Minimize Overhead, Optimize Need”

Efficient authorization management is crucial within the SAP environment for optimizing license costs. MOON Services aim to reduce authorizations to their necessary minimum, ensuring that what SAP users utilize is licensed, while optimizing unused authorizations. Let's explore the three essential MOON services: "MOON License Simulation", "MOON License Quickfix" and "MOON License Service powered by AIRC", each designed to enhance license management.

MOON License Simulation

MOON License Simulation focuses on precisely defining user license types in the SAP S/4HANA system through tailored authorizations to their essential minimum. This service enables companies to manage licenses efficiently and significantly reduce unnecessary costs.

Through simulation, customers can identify potential license cost optimizations when engaging in an authorization redesign with SAP Consulting. The service includes downloading usage data and calculating license costs for a new S/4HANA authorization concept against the requirements of the current STAR Service framework. Customers gain insight into possible license cost optimizations that can be achieved after an authorization redesign.


MOON License Quickfix

The MOON License Quickfix service offers rapid modifications to existing authorization structures, ensuring efficiency in license categorization. By analyzing current authorizations and making immediate role adjustments, companies can implement instant cost-saving measures.

This service focuses on reducing effort by minimizing authorization values and adapting authorization objects. By achieving quick wins in license type optimization, companies can significantly save costs while maintaining operational efficiency.


MOON License Service powered by AIRC

MOON License Service powered by AIRC (Automated Implementation of Role Concept) elevates license cost minimization to a new level, employing advanced automation and SAP Best Practices to refine authorizations. This service is designed to decrease effort and duration in managing roles and authorizations, enabling seamless cost management.

Driven by SAP AI Core automation, MOON AIRC precisely tailors authorizations to the necessary minimum, achieving substantial cost reductions and enhanced security. The service includes scoping, functional and organizational role definitions, and strategic role assignments—all aimed at minimizing license costs. Synchronization capabilities from SAP Signavio ensure a coherent approach to authorization management. In addition to optimizing license costs, this service delivers a high-quality, secure SAP Best Practice authorization concept.


Conclusion

The MOON services are at the forefront of license cost optimization, enabling companies to efficiently reduce authorizations to their necessary minimum. By focusing on precise authorization adjustments and employing automation, MOON Services empower organizations to achieve operational efficiency and substantial cost savings. Harness the potential of MOON Services and navigate your path to optimized license management and reduced overhead.

For more information about the offering send a mail to: security.consulting@sap.com

entry.title: New Cloudification Repository Viewer for Clean Core Governance and Development
entry.content:
This blog is meant to be a quick read — the idea is to cover the new Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer (CRV) features over your morning coffee☕, and kick off a new day of your SAP Clean Core journey.

https://sap.github.io/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc/ 

I am an SAP Clean Core and Extensibility Lifecycle consultant, and I have supported many RISE with SAP customers in establishing Clean Core governance models, solution standardization boards (SSB), and extensibility development guidelines. Through various concrete use cases, I have gained extensive hands-on experience.

From the perspective of Clean Core development and governance, having a unified API repository is of critical importance.

After SAP released the Clean Core Extensibility White Paper and the New Clean Core Level concept, the Cloudification Repository Viewer has now also been updated with a new version, and I am very excited to share its new features with you right away.

SAP Product

In the filter bar, we will see the SAP Products: SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Cloud ERP Private, and SAP BTP ABAP Environment. If the system is SAP Cloud ERP Private, we select SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Release

After selecting SAP Cloud ERP Private, we will then see a Release option. Here, we can choose the Cloud ERP release version and the corresponding SP level. It is worth noting that as the Cloud ERP evolves, the number of available APIs is steadily increasing.

Partner Namespace

One particularly exciting development is the introduction of the “Partner Namespace.” With SAP Clean Core’s certification for partners, certified partners are now able to publish released APIs as well. In my view, this represents a significant step forward for the entire extensibility ecosystem.

State

Next is the “State” field, which is the most interesting part because the Clean Core levels are “hidden” here. This allows us to easily and clearly identify the level mapping.

Here, I would like to highlight a few points for clarification:

  • Custom objects are assigned levels, whereas SAP objects are categorized into states (for example, ‘Classic APIs,’ which place the extension in Level B).

  • Released → Allowed in ABAP Cloud developments (Level A).

  • Deprecated → Still usable in ABAP Cloud developments, but a newer, recommended API exists and should be preferred.

  • Classic API → Usable only in standard ABAP developments, not in ABAP Cloud (Level B).

  • Not to be released → Not permitted in ABAP Cloud developments, but a successor API is available and should be used instead.

  • No API → Not usable in ABAP Cloud, and also not recommended for standard ABAP developments (Level D).

Object Type / Software Component / Application Component

As in the previous version, filtering objects by Object Type, Software Component, or Application Component is also supported.

Label

Within the final Label field, additional details are available — for instance, APIs marked as “transactional-consistent” are suitable for use in RAP-based applications.

To summarize:

  1. The new CRV interface has a clearer layout — first select the Cloud ERP version, then the release version, and then the state/level, which makes the process straightforward.
  2. Released APIs, classic APIs, not-to-be-released APIs, and NO APIs can be presented in a single view, distinguished and filtered by State.
  3. Clean Core levels are shown explicitly, which makes identifying the classification of each API much simpler.
  4. The Clean Core API framework is becoming increasingly standardized, with more and more Level A and B APIs available.
  5. Partner APIs that have been certified are also being included, further expanding the extensibility ecosystem.
  6. Object Type, Software Component, Application Component, and Label are still retained.

With the release of the new CRV version, I’m delighted to have another handy tool added to my Clean Core governance and extensibility development arsenal.

Of course, a single weapon is not enough — we also need to leverage all the Clean Core tools to deliver a true combination punch:

For Clean Core extensibility White paper, please refer to Whitepaper 

For Clean Core ATC Checks, please refer to note 3565942

For Clean Core frameworks, technologies and development patterns, please refer to note 3578329

For SAP Build on BTP, please refer to SAP Build

For Clean Core Extensibility Guide, please refer to Extensibility Guide

For Clean Core governance services, intelligent custom code analysis and transformation, extensibility lifecycle management, and AI tools, please don’t hesitate to reach out to me. I’ll be more than happy to share more real project use cases!

Now you’ve probably finished your coffee. And I hope this quick overview has given you a clear taste of the new CRV features.

As a final note, please

  • don’t forget to upskill on SAP Build on BTP,
  • establish Clean Core Measurement Framework and KPIs
  • and always prioritize Fit-to-Standard and extension on Level A for new development use cases!

Let’s keep moving forward on the Clean Core journey — learning, improving, and building smarter together! 🍻

Thanks! 😊

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 FPS00: Final What's New & Product Assistance
entry.content:
With immediate effect, the documentation for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 is available. You can find this documentation on the current SAP Help Portal pages of SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

To learn more about the changed and new features in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025, access the What’s New information by using the following links:  What's New Viewer for SAP S/4HANA or What's New Viewer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

For any feedback you may have, you can use the commenting feature for What's New.  With this feature, authors can evaluate your feedback and incorporate it into the documentation, if needed. We hope that by opening this channel of communication, we can learn how to further improve our What’s New content for you. To use this feature, you need to be logged into the SAP Help Portal. The feature is only available in the English version of the documents. To learn more about how the feedback process works in SAP Help Portal, see Giving Documentation Feedback.

entry.title: What is new in S/4HANA Manufacturing for Production Engineering & Operations (PEO) in 2025 FPS0
entry.content:
What is new in S/4HANA Manufacturing for Production Engineering & Operations (PEO) in 2025 FPS0

The 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for production engineering and operations (PEO) offers significant enhancements that streamline manufacturing processes, improve operational flexibility, and enhance user experience across the production lifecycle. This blog post explores the key innovations in the areas of product rework capabilities, production engineering efficiency, flexible production operations, and extensibility improvements.

 

Product Rework

PEO now enables comprehensive rework capabilities for products at any time after completion of their production order, including externally procured products. This functionality allows replacement of defective or degraded components identified for completed orders, as well as repairs or maintenance on products that have been in storage or returned from the field. The system provides the same level of traceability for product rework orders as for standard shop floor orders, ensuring complete visibility throughout the process.

 

For more information, see Performing Product Rework | SAP Help Portal.

Production Engineering Efficiency

Automatic Plan-as-Designed with Phantom Flattening

The shop floor BOM in PEO does not expect phantom assemblies. But many customers define mBOMs in PLM systems with phantom assemblies. Using this new capability in PEO, the upstream PLM system can now send mBOMs with phantom assemblies to PEO, which are then automatically processed to create shop floor BOM by doing automated plan-as-design with phantom flattening. Shop floor BOM is created as a mirror of the incoming mBOM but if phantom assemblies are found, they are automatically flattened. The phantom hierarchy information is available for production engineer while working with shop floor routing management and also for production worker while using Perform Work Apps.

Business benefits include:

  • Valuable information on phantom hierarchies is not lost
  • Huge time savings when combined with workflow automation

For more information, see Automatic Plan-As-Designed | SAP Help Portal.

Work Instructions: Usability Improvements

Usability has been improved in both interactive and non-interactive work instructions. When adding references to inspection characteristics and PRTs, you can now add multiple references in one step. Multiple selection is also now supported when you add document links.

 

 

In addition, logical components can now be cross-referenced in work instructions.

For more information, see How to Maintain Work Instructions for Operation Activities | SAP Help Portal.

Manage Production Model: Support for Unitized Products

The Manage Production Models - Materials app now enables you to create and manage production models for unitized products. You can define production models at unit level to support different customer requirements, thereby optimizing your production planning.

A Parameter Effectivity section has been added to the details page for components, operations, and operation activities.

 

You can also release a production model version for a subset of the MBOM effectivity range.

 

For more information, see Manage Production Model – Materials | SAP Help Portal.

 

Manage Production Model: Create Sales-Order-Specific BOM and Routing for Non-Configurable Products

 


The Manage Production Models - Engineer-to-Order app now supports the creation of ETO production models for non-configurable materials such as material type HALB (Semifinished Product) or FERT (Finished Product). A simple guided procedure takes users through the steps to create an ETO production model using a sales order for a non-configurable material and engineer it further by adding components and production steps. This enables meeting special customer requirements even when the material in the sales order is not configurable.

For more information, see Manage Production Model – Engineer-to-Order | SAP Help Portal.

 

Assign Documents to Operations in Routings

You can now assign documents at operation level in shop floor routings. Documents applicable to all operation activities of a specific operation now only need to be assigned once, saving time and effort while eliminating the risk of different and contradictory information being displayed for each operation activity.

 

For more information, see How to Assign Documents to Operations | SAP Help Portal.

Usability Improvements for Shop Floor Routing Template Handling

To allow for easier organization of templates in the folder view, you can now cut a template and paste it at a different position in the structure.

 

When you display the template library, the system automatically filters the list of templates by the production plant of the template that you're editing. This improves performance and usability by reducing the number of templates initially displayed.

 

 

Flexible Production Operations

Perform OA: Usability Improvement for Displaying Documents

In the Perform Operation Activity app, document service control has been replaced by a responsive table to enable file previews within the app. You can now view and download documents and attachments more easily directly within the app.

 

For more information, see Perform Operation Activity | SAP Help Portal.

Parallel Operations Using Parallel Sequences

PEO shop floor routing now supports the creation of sequences for scheduling order operations to run in parallel, like classic routings. A parallel sequence branches from and returns to operations in a reference sequence, with operations in a parallel sequence performed in parallel to operations in the reference sequence. This functionality provides greater process and scheduling flexibility to reduce production time, better utilize resources, and support different manufacturing scenarios.

 

For more information, see How to Create Parallel Sequences | SAP Help Portal.

Alternative Components: Simple Discontinuation

Sometimes prescribed components may be in shortage in shop floor. Using the definition of alternative components, the production engineer can specify alternative components that can be used in such cases. In addition to defining alternative components in BOM, PEO now supports the use of global alternatives defined using simple discontinuation in the material master record.

 

 

Components in the production order can be exchanged for follow-up materials that have been defined using simple discontinuation.

 

This provides more flexibility to replace components in a production order due to defects, stock shortages, or changes in safety requirements without having to update the BOM.

PEO tracks the use of global alternatives in the end-to-end process.

For more information, see Using Global Alternatives | SAP Help Portal.

Extended Quality Check (EQC) Groups

PEO provides the capability of extended quality check (EQC) to enable modelling of regulatory and compliance requirements like first article inspection (FAI), first piece inspection (FPI) or other kind of compliances during production. With EQC production engineer can define conditional operations, operation activities or data collection which generally not applicable for normal production but can be exposed in production orders which requires such extended checks.

PEO has introduced EQC groups to support partial extended quality checks. You define EQC groups in Customizing. Through the assignment of EQC groups to operation activities and inspection characteristics in the shop floor routing, it’s now possible to implement partial extended quality checks. During creation of a shop floor order, EQC groups can be selected, resulting in only those operation activities and inspection characteristics assigned to the selected EQC groups being included in the shop floor order, along with non-EQC-relevant operation activities.

In the example below the production engineer has defined some additional activities tagged with relevant EQC Groups. While creating the order, it can be identified as an order which requires for example in this case ‘Full FAI’ or ‘Partial FAI’ or ‘First Piece’ and depending upon these relevant activities are exposed in the order. Multiple EQC groups can also be assigned to an order.

 

Benefits include:

  • Capability to perform delta or selected quality checks after a full EQC
  • Flexibility to perform partial quality checks across orders if production-related issues prevent a full EQC in a single order

For more information, see Extended Quality Checks | SAP Help Portal.

Qualifications for Buyoff Steps

HR qualifications can now be assigned to each buyoff step in an operation activity.

 


This functionality allows control over who can approve buyoff steps at production completion, ensuring higher quality assurance and improving compliance and audit readiness.

For more information, see How to Assign Buyoffs to Operation Activities | SAP Help Portal.

Retain Serial Number Group Across Operation Activities (Pull Scenario)

 
 

 


Production operators can now copy a serial number group that was completed at the previous operation activity to a new group at the selected operation activity when starting an operation activity in the My Work Queue app (pull scenario).

 

 

This provides more flexibility in copying serial number groups, especially when the production operator performing an operation activity is not the same operator who completed the previous operation activity.

For more information, see How to Copy Serial Number Groups from Previous Operation Activity | SAP Help Portal.

Data Collection: Capture Test Equipment Used

When collecting data in the Perform Operation Activity app, you can now select the test equipment used for a specific inspection characteristic.

 

Benefits of this feature are:

  • Improved traceability and compliance
  • Allows the operator to record unplanned test equipment that was used for the IC

For more information, see How to Record Inspection Characteristics | SAP Help Portal.

Exposing Inspection Method to Production Worker

Inspection methods can now be referenced in shop floor routings. This means that production engineers can:

  • Reference an inspection method when adding an IC.
  • Include the inspection method when referencing ICs in interactive and non-interactive work instructions.

The production operator can navigate to the inspection method from the Perform Operation Activity app, view the details, and then navigate back to the operation activity.

 

For more information, see How to Assign Inspection Method to Inspection Characteristics | SAP Help Portal.

Other New Capabilities

Modernization of Tables in Perform OA App Using Smart Tables

SAP Fiori smart tables are now used to display component data, PRTs, and data collection for operation activities that have simple work instructions or no work instructions. This modernization provides app extensibility for key users and delivers better look and feel and behavior of the UI.

 

Improved Extensibility in Authoring of Interactive Work Instructions

New Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) have been introduced, which you can use to fill custom fields for components, inspection characteristics, and PRTs that are referenced in both interactive and non-interactive work instructions

 

The custom field values are then displayed in the work instructions in the Perform Operation Activity app.

Want to Find Out More?

You can find more information on all new features provided in SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for production engineering and operations (PEO) Release 2025 FPS0 here:

  • What's New | SAP Help Portal  – just go to Manufacturing for Production Engineering and Operations

entry.title: SAP Joule for Developers Expands to Private Cloud: Accelerating ABAP Innovation and Transformation
entry.content:
Key Highlights

  • Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now available in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition 2025.
  • New Custom Code Migration capabilities accelerate the transformation of classic ERP code to S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including:
    • Documentation Chat - Get accurate answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications.
    • ABAP Program Explain - Understand the business purpose and logic of legacy code.
    • Explain for SAP S/4HANA Test Cockpit Issues - Diagnose and resolve S/4HANA-related Test Cockpit issues using context from simplification items and cookbooks.

Earlier this year, SAP introduced Joule for Developers — a set of embedded artificial intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, including ABAP, that helps developers accelerate application and extension development, reduce costs, and boost productivity.

Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now available for S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition, version 2025, providing comprehensive support for ABAP Cloud use cases. The release also introduces the first Custom Code Migration capabilities, bringing a powerful suite of AI-assisted capabilities purpose-built for ABAP development and cloud delivery.

Best of all, Joule for Developers remains free of charge, enabling customers and partners to integrate it into daily operations and accelerate innovation without commercial barriers.

 

What’s Included

This release for Private Cloud delivers AI-powered support for the core development scenarios ABAP developers rely on every day. Key capabilities include:

  • inline code completion,
  • ABAP/CDS code explanation,
  • automated unit test generation for ABAP and ABAP core data services (CDS),
  • RAP business objects generation,
  • RAP predictive business logic, and
  • OData consumption.

All capabilities are designed to accelerate development, improve code quality, and boost productivity from day one. Additionally, this release introduces the first wave of Custom Code Migration capabilities, designed to accelerate the move from classic SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Cloud Edition. These AI-powered features simplify code analysis and adaptation by:

  • Providing Documentation Chat for quick answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications:

 

  • Using ABAP Program Explain to clarify the business purpose and implementation logic of legacy code:

 

  • Explaining ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) findings with step-by-step guidance on how to fix the issues, based on simplification items and technical documentation:

 

All capabilities are designed to reduce manual effort, speed up migration projects, and help your teams to modernize their ABAP landscapes with great confidence.

The ABAP AI software development kit, powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management, is now available and offers centralized access to the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core. It leverages the same robust platform SAP uses internally, delivering proven, production-grade infrastructure to customer landscapes. With simplified configuration and governance, development teams can adopt AI capabilities quickly, providing a significant boost to integration efforts.

 

Why This Matters

Private cloud customers require strict governance, security, and operational control - yet they also seek the speed and innovation modern AI-driven development delivers. This release addresses both priorities by enabling:

  • faster development cycles with AI-assisted coding and test generation,
  • stronger knowledge transfer through automated code explanations and copilot interactions,
  • higher delivery quality with automated testing and code migration support, and
  • secure innovation within controlled environments.

 

Looking Ahead

We’re building on this momentum with a series of targeted deliveries aligned to upcoming releases across the BTP ABAP Environment and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Planned updates for BTP ABAP Environment 2511, 2602, and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 include:

  • documentation generation capabilities,
  • enhanced explanations for reports in the Custom Code Migration application,
  • AI-enabled insights on Clean Core–related ATC findings directly within the Custom Code Migration application,
  • code migration and adaptation proposals to support developers working on RISE code adaptation,
  • ABAP CDS annotation and metadata extension generation, and
  • ABAP CDS analytical model generation.

These enhancements will extend Joule’s impact beyond code completion and test generation, supporting documentation, migration and Clean Core compliance, analytical use cases, and addressing more stages of the end-to-end development lifecycle.

 

Free Offer Extended

SAP Joule for Developers will remain free of charge. The extended promotion ensures that all customers and partners can continue to use Joule for Developers capabilities for free.

Access can be requested using the material numbers 8019124 (customers) and 8019541 (TDD partners). This offer now extends beyond the BTP ABAP environment and SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition to include SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition customers running the latest 2025 release.

 

Closing Remarks

SAP Joule for Developers’ delivery for Private Cloud is a significant milestone — combining end-to-end ABAP Cloud with AI use cases, innovative code migration scenarios, and a standardized ABAP AI SDK to bring practical AI assistance directly into everyday development workflows.

With extended free of charge access, we invite every customer and partner to explore SAP Joule for Developers, push its boundaries, and help shape the future of AI-assisted ABAP development.

Start using SAP Joule for Developers today and join us in building the next generation of intelligent, AI-driven ABAP innovation.

For a deeper dive, read the blog post by Simona Marincei, head of ABAP AI.

Learn more about SAP Joule for Developers capabilities here.

Have fun and stay tuned for TechEd soon!

Best,
Sebastian

 

Prerequisites

You have a customer account on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and a development system on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and you have prepared the following:

  • Subscription to SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Subscription to SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities
  • Established trust to your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in your BTP Subaccount, see this link
  • Your user needs Administrator access to your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant
  • Your system needs to be configured so that it trusts server certificates according to the "required" section of the BTP Trust Store.
  • Your system needs to use a client certificate issued by a CA listed in the "required" section of the BTP Trust Store. One way to obtain a client certificate can be found on Manage Destination Certificates (under "Generate a Certificate").
  • You've successfully applied SAP Note 3627794 .
  • Your ABAP system needs to support TLS 1.3. If TLS 1.3 is not enabled, refer to SAP Note 3318423  to activate it.

 

Configuration steps in your SAP BTP subaccount

  1. In your BTP subaccount, navigate to Entitlements. You’ll see a table with all entitlements it already has.
  2. Select Configure Entitlements > Add Service Plans. A popover appears with all entitlements available for your directory/subaccount.
  3. Select the service SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities and then the plan “default”
  4. Select the amount of quota
  5. Select Add Service Plans.
  6. Select Save.

 

  1. Navigate to your subaccount in the SAP BTP cockpit
  2. Go to Services > Service Marketplace.
  3. Choose the SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities tile.
  4. Choose Create and select Plan default




  5. Once the service is created, go to your IAS and navigate to Users & Authorizations > Groups
  6. Check that the group j4d-admin was successfully created
  7. Add your admin user to the created j4a-admin group

     

  8. Navigate to your subaccount in the SAP BTP cockpit
  9. In the navigation go to Services >Instances & Subscriptions
  10. Choose the SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities tile.
  11. Click on Go to Application




  12. Maintain Certificate Mappings app should be opened



    Configuration in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 system

    1. Go to your ABAP system, open the transaction APPLDESTCC
    2. Select scenario HTTP - Application Destination and click on Execute


    3. Next, select AIC_ADT_HTTP_PROXY and open the context menu. Choose Create New Application Destination. Now, you're asked to enter the details of your application destination.


       



    4. Enter an Application Destination Name of your choice and select the check mark. 



    5. Now, first enter a Description and select the checkboxes Active and Default.

    6. Fill in the information in the Technical Settings tab:
      1. Target System Settings: In the Host field, enter https://proxy.<your region>.hub.j4a.services.sap. As Protocol, select HTTPS.
      2. (Optional) HTTP Proxy Options: This information is not mandatory.

        Note The region you enter in https://proxy.<your region>.hub.j4a.services.sap must be the same region (not technical key) that you chose for your subaccount, for example "eu10". See Regions and API Endpoints for the ABAP Environment


         

    7. Choose the Logon tab
      1. General Settings: Select Connection to External Server.
      2. Logon Procedure: Select Client Certificate and choose the certificate you wish to use from the dropdown menu
      3. Select Save. You've successfully maintained the connection.

         

    8. Now, continue in your subaccount in the SAP BTP Cockpit
      1. Select the SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities subscription you have just created (see Subscribing to SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities), or open its details and select Go to Application. You are forwarded to the Maintain Certificate Mappings page.
      2. In the Certificate Mappings section, select Create to receive a one-time password (OTP).
      3. Copy the OTP.

        Note: the OTP is valid for five minutes. If you need a new one, close the pop-up and click on Create again.


    9.  Go to your corresponding ABAP system and run report AIC_ADT_PROXY_CERTIFICATE. Select Execute.
      1. Paste the one-time password that you've copied in the previous step
      2. (Optional) If you wish to use a new certificate that you haven't used in step 1, select Use Custom SSL Client PSE ID. Click in the Client PSE ID field and choose the new certificate from the value help. Now, you can go back to step 1 and switch to the new certificate.
      3. Select Execute



      4. You've successfully registered your certificate!




         

 You can now create a new ABAP Project in ADT (using its latest version) and check out SAP Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities
